;;中位的 Joey Fatone、NSYNC 的 Lance Bass 和 Justin Timberlake 颁发奖项泰勒·斯威夫特（最左边）于 2023 年 9 月 12 日在新泽西州纽瓦克保德信中心举行的 MTV 音乐录影带颁奖典礼上凭借《Anti-Hero》获得最佳流行音乐奖（摄影：Charles Sykes/Invision/美联社）;< /div>;

;泰勒·斯威夫特 (Taylor Swift) 凭借其;Anti-Hero;音乐视频荣获 2023 年 MTV 音乐录影带大奖 (VMA) 最高奖项。

;

;该音乐网络的年度奖项演出在新泽西州纽瓦克的保德信中心举行。

;

;“这令人难以置信。事实上，这是一个粉丝投票的奖项对我来说意义重大，”斯威夫特在获奖感言中说道。 “我不敢相信一年前我就发布了;Midnights;专辑。”

;

;当晚的第一位主持人来自男性音乐剧 NSYNC。他们重聚，将最佳;流行;视频奖颁给了斯威夫特。

;

;斯威夫特是获得提名最多的表演者。随后斯威夫特重返舞台，凭借《反英雄》获得年度歌曲奖和最佳导演奖。

;

;表演者总共获得了九个奖项。其中包括首次在 VMA 演出中获得由女性组成的提名团体的年度艺术家。

;

;Ice Spice，与 Swift 合作过《Karma (Remix)》; ，赢得了最佳新人奖。

;

;节目中充满了新音乐，其中充满了妮琪·米娜 (Nicki Minaj) 的歌曲，她也是;主持人;。米娜表演了新歌;Last Time I saw You;。然后，她表演了即将推出的;Pink Friday 2 ;专辑中的一首曲目。

;
;;;Megan Thee Stallion 于 2023 年 9 月 12 日在新泽西州纽瓦克保德信中心举行的 MTV 音乐录影带颁奖典礼上表演（查尔斯·赛克斯/Invision/美联社拍摄）;;;

;颁奖典礼的重点是展示音乐的国际影响力。韩国流行音乐或韩国流行音乐男孩组合 Tomorrow X Together 和巴西艺术家 Anitta 共同推出了一首新歌，;Back for More;。

;

;另一支韩国流行音乐组合 Stray Kids，表演了歌曲;S-Class;。墨西哥歌手 Peso Pluma 演唱了一首名为《Lady Gaga》的歌曲，哥伦比亚歌手 Karol G 演唱了《Oki Doki》和另一首歌曲《Tá OK（混音版）》。;。 p>;

;蒂芙尼·哈迪什 (Tiffany Haddish) 颁发了新奖项组“最佳非洲节奏”奖。非洲节奏是受非洲和美国黑人文化影响的音乐。雷玛和赛琳娜·戈麦斯凭借流行歌曲《Calm Down》获奖。 ;

;

;“非洲就在家里！”雷马在获奖感言中说道。戈麦斯说：“我想把我所有的爱送给尼日利亚，谢谢。”

;

;哥伦比亚明星夏奇拉获得了视频先锋奖，并表演了她的流行歌曲的混音。

;

; “MTV，谢谢你从我 18 岁起就成为我职业生涯中如此重要的一部分，”夏奇拉说道。她还感谢她带来观看演出的父母和孩子。

;

;“这是为了你们，我的人民，我的拉丁美洲人民，无论是在这个国家还是国外，”她用西班牙语说道。

;

;吹牛老爹 (Diddy) 荣获玛丽·J·布莱姬 (Mary J. Blige) 及其女儿钱斯·库姆斯 (Chance Combs) 颁发的全球偶像奖。他是继 2022 年的 ;Red Hot; Chili Peppers 和 2021 年的 Foo Fighters 后第三位获得该奖项的艺人。

;

;这位艺术家还在自 2005 年以来首次获得 VMA。这次表演收录了他一些最受欢迎的歌曲，例如 ;Bad Boy for Life; 和 ;Mo Money Mo Problems;。

; < Lil Wayne 以他的新单曲 ;Kat Food 的表演拉开了演出的序幕。 ;奥利维亚罗德里戈随后将她的;吸血鬼;音乐录影带带到舞台上，然后表演;让他回来！;

;

;后来，安妮塔赢得了“最佳”第二年获得拉丁语奖。在获奖感言中，她笑着说：“我要感谢我自己。”她补充道，“因为我工作太努力了！”

;

;表演者弗伦斯·蒙大拿颁奖，引起了人们对为摩洛哥地震受害者提供援助的努力的关注。这位表演者在摩洛哥长大。

;

;VMA 演出以庆祝音乐形式;嘻哈;诞生 50 周年而结束。其中包括 Nicki Minaj、Lil Wayne、LL Cool J 和 Run-DMC 的 DMC。

;

;我是 Gregory Stachel。

;;这张由麦考利图书馆/康奈尔鸟类学实验室提供的图像显示了一只冬鹪鹩。 （詹姆斯·戴维斯/麦考利图书馆/康奈尔大学鸟类学实验室，美联社）;
;

;Tracee Herbaugh 住在马萨诸塞州波士顿地区。

;

;Herbaugh 认为她独自一人在<最近，她在后院使用 Merlin Bird ID 应用程序。她听了才知道，自己周围有超过12种鸟类。

;

;有熟悉的蓝鸟、红雀和金翅雀。但该应用程序还识别出了烟囱雨燕、北方闪烁鸟、鱼鸦、杀鹿和灰猫鸟等鸟类。

;

;该应用程序识别出的两种鸟类，非常大角鸮，甚至有一个红色;点< /strong>; 他们的名字旁边。红点意味着这是一次罕见的景象。

;

;赫博写道：“谁知道所有这些鸟都在一个院子里？”

;

;康奈尔鸟类学实验室是梅林鸟的制造者ID。该应用程序于 2014 年发布。最初，该应用程序仅通过视觉识别鸟类，称为“照片 ID”。用户回答了一系列问题来帮助识别这只鸟，例如日期、面积、颜色和大小。该应用程序在大流行期间变得流行，当时人们越来越想要户外活动。

;

;2021 年，康奈尔实验室添加了声音 ID，可以通过声音识别鸟类。仅在美国，Merlin 的声音 ID 就可以识别 700 多种鸟类。目前，全球有超过 700 万人使用 Merlin Bird ID。

;

;Alli Smith 在康奈尔实验室从事 Merlin 项目工作。史密斯说，通过声音观鸟“打开了一个全新的世界”。史密斯补充说，即使你看不到这些鸟，“你也可以听到它们美妙的歌声，并且知道它们正在分享你的邻居。”

;

;其他鸟类识别应用程序包括 Audubon Bird Guide、ChirpOMatic、Picture Bird和智能鸟。

;
;;;文件 - 左起，北红雀、美国金翅雀和美国知更鸟。 （美联社照片）;
;

;;与人联系;

;

;赫博表示，除了鸟类之外，该应用程序还帮助她与全国各地的人们重新建立联系。

;

;当赫博在社交媒体上分享她的鸟类清单时，两个也使用该应用程序的儿时朋友向她发送了消息。

;

;她在蒙大拿州的亲戚分享了一份清单，其中包括鹰、猛禽和蜂鸟。现在，即使是她年幼的孩子，只要听到不熟悉的鸟叫声，他们也会很快使用该应用程序。

;

;到目前为止，Herbaugh 已经在她的名单上识别出了 45 种鸟类。她说，现在是她的孩子们在推动她在鸟类名单上获得更多的名录。

;

;史密斯说，当人们写信给梅林时，他们经常谈论联系。她说：“周围有很多小奇迹，与人们分享这些奇迹很有趣。”

;

;我是多萝西·甘迪。

;朝鲜领导人金正恩和俄罗斯弗拉基米尔·普京总统周三在俄罗斯远东的新航天发射场会面。

;

;普京向金正恩展示了东方航天发射场，并讨论了将朝鲜;宇航员;送入太空的可能性。 ;参观;结束后，普京和金正恩就世界问题和可能的合作领域进行了几个小时的讨论。

;

;午餐时，金正恩为普京的健康、为“胜利”干杯。伟大的俄罗斯”和韩俄友谊。他预测俄罗斯将在他所说的乌克兰战争中与西方的“神圣战斗”中取得胜利。

;

;

;詹姆斯·尼克西 (James Nixey) 是《朝鲜战争》的导演。伦敦研究小组查塔姆研究所的俄罗斯和欧亚大陆项目。他表示，俄罗斯无法为乌克兰战争生产足够的武器，与朝鲜的任何协议都将确保满足当前的需求。

;;;在人造卫星发布的这张泳池照片中通讯社，俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京（左中）和朝鲜领导人金正恩（中右）于 2023 年 9 月 13 日参观阿穆尔州东方航天发射场。（摄影：Mikhail Metzel / POOL /法新社）;

; Thu, 14 Sep 2023 06:07:04 +0800 AI Development Requires Large Amounts of Waterhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/ai-development-requires-large-amounts-of-water/7265493.html

;;9 月 5 日星期二，Microsoft 数据中心附近的 35 号州际公路上显示交通情况2023 年，爱荷华州西得梅因。 （美联社照片/Charlie Neibergall）;
;

;研究人员表示，用于创建人工智能 (AI) 系统的方法需要大量的水。因此，人们呼吁人工智能开发者减少用水量，并对他们使用的环境资源承担更多责任。

;

;美联社最近报道了美国的用水量总部位于 OpenAI 的公司，推出了 ChatGPT 人工智能工具。 ChatGPT 是一种所谓的“聊天机器人”，旨在与人类顺利交互并执行高级写作。此类工具也被称为“生成式人工智能”或“大型语言模型”。

;

;用于创建大型语言模型的开发和训练方法需要强大的计算系统。这个过程使用大量电力并产生大量热量。数据中心运营商注入水以保持设备冷却。

;

;Open AI（由软件制造商微软支持）在爱荷华州西得梅因运营着一系列数据中心。这座位于该州中部的城市拥有约 68,000 人。

;

;“他们正在以最快的速度建设这些城市，”微软刚来时担任该市市长的史蒂夫·盖尔 (Steve Gaer) 说道。 。他说，这家软件制造商之所以被这座城市所吸引，是因为它在改善公共项目方面所做的努力。这位前官员还表示，微软提供了大量税收来支持这些努力。

;

;“但是，”盖尔在谈到该公司时说道，“他们对自己正在做的事情非常保密。 ”

;

;2020 年，微软表示正在为 OpenAI 开发世界上最强大的超级计算机之一。当时，它没有指定爱荷华市为该项目的所在地。微软将这项工作描述为一个“单一系统”，拥有大量;半导体;和处理器来支持人工智能工作负载。

;

;5 月下旬，微软总裁 Brad Smith 首次发表公开评论关于该公司位于西得梅因的新“人工智能超级计算数据中心”。他指出该中心的建立是为了支持 ChatGPT 系统的开发工作。

;

;从附近的浣熊河和得梅因河取水来冷却 Microsoft-OpenAI 计算设备 ;AP; 报告。微软在最新的环境报告中表示，从 2021 年到 2022 年，其全球用水量增长了 34%，达到近 17 亿加仑。行业专家认为，这一大幅增长与公司的人工智能研究直接相关。

;

;“可以公平地说，大部分增长都归功于人工智能，”任少雷说。他是加州大学河滨分校的研究员，一直在研究 ChatGPT 等人工智能产品对环境的影响。

;

;在今年晚些时候发表的一篇论文中，任正非的团队估计 ChatGPT 占用了 500每次有人向该工具询问一系列 5 到 50 个问题时，就会产生毫升水。该估计还包括公司通常不测量的间接使用量。这包括用于冷却为数据中心供电的发电厂的水。

;

;“大多数人不;意识到;;底层;ChatGPT 的资源使用情况， ”任正非说道。 “如果您不了解资源的使用情况，那么我们就无法帮助;保护;资源。”

;

;Ren 指出，Google 报告称水资源增长了 20%同一时期内的使用情况。他认为，增长很大程度上与这家美国搜索引擎公司的人工智能开发工作有关。

;

;微软在最近给美联社的一份声明中表示，它正在投资研究以衡量人工智能活动对环境的影响。该公司承诺致力于“在培训和应用方面使大型系统更加高效”。

;

;OpenAI 在自己的声明中表示它对计算能力的最佳利用进行了“深思熟虑”。它说：“我们认识到训练大型模型可能会消耗大量能源和水。” 西得梅因 2022 年政府文件称，该市“只会考虑微软未来的数据中心项目”，如果这些项目可以“演示并;实施;”技术，以;显着;减少当前水平的用水量。

;

;我是 Bryan Lynn。

; Wed, 13 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Unusual Bird-like Dinosaur Discovered in Chinahttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/unusual-bird-like-dinosaur-discovered-in-china/7263773.html

;;鸟状恐龙福建猎龙的生命重建。 （赵闯/路透社讲义）;
;

;大约148至1.5亿年前，一种奇特的恐龙生活在中国东南部，它的大小像鸡，像鸟，腿长，手臂很像翅膀。它不寻常的身体表明它要么跑得快，要么生活在水边。

;

;科学家表示，上周他们在福建地区发现了一种恐龙的;化石;，他们将其命名为“福建猎龙”。他们说它生活在地球历史上的侏罗纪时期。

;

;研究人员表示，新的恐龙发现提供了有关鸟类如何发育或进化的重要阶段的更多信息。

; <研究负责人王敏表示，恐龙是否应该被称为鸟类的问题取决于人们如何定义鸟类。他是中国科学院古脊椎动物与古人类研究所的;古生物学家;。

;

;当被问及用什么词来形容福建猎手时，王回答说：“我会说‘<强>;奇怪;。'福建猎龙与任何现代鸟类都相差甚远。”

;

;鸟类是由侏罗纪晚期的兽脚类恐龙演化而来。已知最古老的鸟类是始祖鸟，其历史可追溯到约 1.5 亿年前的德国。

;

;王说，福建猎鸟属于鸟类类群，该类群包括所有鸟类及其最接近的非鸟类恐龙亲戚。< /p>;

;该化石是去年十月发现的。它基本完整，但缺少动物的头部和部分脚部。这使得科学家很难推测它吃什么以及如何生活。

;

;福建猎龙的小腿骨（胫骨）长度是其大腿骨（股骨）的两倍。这些尺寸在兽脚类动物中是特殊的。兽脚类恐龙包括暴龙等所有食肉恐龙。

;

;王说，福建猎龙确实有翅膀，但是否会飞还不清楚。王说，根据它的骨骼结构，即使它真的飞了，也可能飞得不好。

;

;王说，化石不包括;羽毛;。但是，这种动物的近亲和几乎所有类似鸟类的兽脚亚目动物都有羽毛。许多恐龙也有羽毛。

;

;王说，“如果福建猎龙有羽毛，那就不足为奇了。”

;

;根据它的长腿，研究人员认为它生活在两部分中可能的方式——要么是快速奔跑，要么是靠近水的地方，类似于鹤或苍鹭等鸟类。

;

;王对这个谜团有自己的看法：“我会把钱押在跑步者身上，”这位科学家说。< /p>;

;我是格雷戈里·斯塔切尔。

; Wed, 13 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Google“s Search Engine at Center of Antitrust Trialhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/google-s-search-engine-at-center-of-antitrust-trial/7265268.html
;;2023 年 9 月 12 日星期二 21:58:00 GMT;
;;
;;9 月 11 日，纽约两台设备上的搜索结果中显示各种 Google 徽标，2023 年。（美联社照片/理查德·德鲁）;
;

;美国司法部周二指责谷歌利用其互联网搜索引擎排挤竞争对手并限制新创意。

;

;肯尼思·丁泽 (Kenneth Dintzer) 是司法部的首席律师。他说，“此案关系到互联网的未来，以及谷歌的搜索引擎是否会面临有意义的竞争。”

;

;在接下来的 10 周内，联邦律师和州总检察长将试图证明谷歌通过使其搜索引擎成为人们日常使用的软件和设备的首选，不公平地控制了对自己有利的市场。

;

;该案与针对该公司的;反垄断;审判类似。 1998年，计算机软件制造商微软。当时，政府指责微软利用其在软件领域的优势，迫使计算机制造商使用其其他产品，包括Internet Explorer网络浏览器。此案以阻止微软完全控制市场的限制而告终。

;

;许多 Google 产品，包括 Chrome 网络浏览器、Gmail、YouTube 和在线地图都非常受欢迎。但没有一家能够控制市场并变得像其互联网搜索引擎一样有价值。

;

;政府指责谷歌每年支付数十亿美元，使其搜索引擎成为 iPhone 和苹果等网络浏览器的首选。 Safari 和 Mozilla 的 Firefox。法律诉讼指出，谷歌还要求其搜索引擎成为许多制造商智能手机使用的Android操作系统的一部分。

;

;Dintzer表示，“这是谷歌的说法：要么接受，要么放弃。” He said that Google's moves prevented Apple from developing a search engine of its own.

;

;Google argues that it faces many competitors although it controls about 90 percent of the internet search market. The company says it faces competition from search engines such as Microsoft's Bing and DuckDuckGo and websites like Amazon and Yelp. These websites let users ask questions about what to buy or where to go.

;

;The company also argues that it faces competition from new technology like artificial intelligence (AI). Microsoft, for example, is adding AI abilities from its partner Open AI to its Bing search engine. That move in early February forced Goggle to equip its search engine with results that come from AI-aided processes.

;

;Google says users can always use any other search engine. But continuous improvements to its search engine are the reason why users keep coming back. It is a process that made the name Google ;synonymous; with looking things up on the internet.

;

;However, critics say the quality of search results has decreased. They note that Google uses its engine to sell advertisements. The company brings attention to its products over those of competitors.

;

;Today, the stock market value of Google's parent company, Alphabet, is $1.7 trillion. The company employs 182,000 people. Most of the money Google makes comes from $224 billion in yearly ad sales. The sales come through a network of digital services that are linked by the search engine, which answers billions of requests a day.

;

;I'm Caty Weaver.

;

;

; Wed, 13 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 US Schools Help Students Behind in Mathhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/us-schools-help-students-behind-in-math/7246248.html

;;Giada Gambino, 10, left, uses her smartphone to consult a voice assistant about a math problem. (AP Photo/Michael Wyke);
;

;Across the United States, schools are working hard to help students catch up in math.

;

;Test scores after the pandemic show just how behind students are. On average, education experts say American students' math knowledge is about half a school year behind where it should be.

;

;Children lost ground on reading tests, too, but the math declines were more severe. Experts say online learning made it more difficult for math instruction. It was harder for teachers to guide students over a screen or see weaknesses in their skills. At home, parents were more likely to read with their children than to practice math.

;

;The result: students' math skills declined around the nation. And students are not recovering as quickly as educators hoped. Educators worry about how they will perform in high school and whether science, technology and medical fields will be available to them.

;

;Students had been making progress on national math tests since 1990. But over the past year, fourth- and eighth-;grade; math scores fell to the lowest levels in about 20 years. The information comes from the National Assessment of Educational Progress, known as the “Nation's Report Card."

;

;“It's a generation's worth of progress lost,” said Andrew Ho. He is a professor at Harvard University's Graduate School of Education.

;

;Jennifer Matthews teaches eighth grade at Moultrie Middle School in Mount Pleasant, South Carolina. She said her students have shown little interest in understanding her pre-algebra and Algebra I lessons.

;

;“They don't ;allow; themselves to process the material. They don't allow themselves to think, 'This might take a day to understand or learn,'” she said.

;

;Many students lack an understanding of math ;concepts;. Basic ;fractions;, for example, continue to confuse many of them, she said.

;

;Using federal pandemic money, some schools have added ;tutors;. Some have started new approaches to teaching to help in the recovery. But that money will run out by next September before many children have caught up.

;

;Like other school systems across the country, Jefferson County Schools in Birmingham, Alabama, saw students' math skills fall from 2019 to 2021. Using pandemic aid, the system placed math ;coaches; in all middle schools.

;

;The coaches help teachers learn new and better ways to teach students. About 1 in 5 public schools in the United States have a math coach, federal data says. The efforts appear to be working: State testing shows math scores have started to increase for most of the Jefferson County middle schools.

;
;;;The Gambino family works on math worksheets as they go through homework from school at the dining room table in their home Wednesday, Aug. 23, 2023, in Spring, Texas. (AP Photo/Michael Wyke);
;

;Adding to the difficulty of catching kids up is the debate over how math should be taught. Some say schools should center procedural learning, like teaching kids to memorize how to solve problems step-by-step. Others prefer conceptual understanding, in which students learn ;underlying; math relationships.

;

;Kevin Dykema is president of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. He said many people do not think of math as a fun subject. But “When people start to understand what's going on, in whatever you're learning but especially in math, you develop a new ;appreciation; for it.”

;

;Sarah Powell is a professor at the University of Texas at Austin who researches math instruction. She said teaching math should not be either one way or another way. A change too far in the conceptual direction, she said, risks losing students who have not fully learned basic math skills.

;

;Even at a nationally recognized ;magnet school;, the effect of the pandemic on students' math skills is clear. At the Townview School of Science and Engineering in Dallas, the incoming ninth graders in Lance Barasch's summer program needed to relearn the meaning of words like “;term;” and “;coefficient;.”

;

;Barasch was not surprised that the students were missing some skills after their middle school years during the pandemic.

;

;The hope is that by taking a step back, students can begin to move forward.

;

;I'm Dan Novak.

;

;

; Wed, 13 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Drug Traffickers Use Banana Industry in Ecuador for Shippinghttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/drug-traffickers-use-banana-industry-in-ecuador-for-shipping/7258885.html
;;Mon, 11 Sep 2023 21:55:26 GMT;
;;
;;Recently harvested bananas are washed at a farm in Los Rios, Ecuador, Tuesday, Aug. 15, 2023. Bananas headed to a commercial port must meet long-established beauty standards of the export market. (AP Photo/Martin Mejia);
;

;Ecuador is increasingly at the meeting point of two worldwide trades: bananas and cocaine.

;

;The South American country is the world's largest exporter of bananas with about 6.5 million metric tons a year. Its neighbors, Peru and Colombia, are the world's largest cocaine producers.

;

;Drug traffickers find containers filled with bananas the perfect vehicle to ;smuggle; their product.

;

;Drug trafficking has since brought extreme violence across this once-peaceful nation. Shootings, murders, kidnappings and ;extortions; have become part of daily life. That is especially true in the Pacific port city and banana-shipping center of Guayaquil.

;

;The country was shocked when Fernando Villavicencio, a presidential candidate known for his tough position on organized crime, was shot to death on August 9. He had accused the Ecuadorian Los Choneros criminal group and its imprisoned leader of threatening him and his campaign team days before the killing.

;

;In addition to being close to cocaine production, drug smugglers from Mexico, Colombia and the Balkans in Europe have also set up operations in Ecuador. That is because the country uses the US dollar; its laws and ;institutions; are weak; and criminal groups like Los Choneros are ready to work.

;

;A record 2,304 metric tons of cocaine was produced in 2021 around the world, mostly in Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. That year, nearly a third of the cocaine seized by officials in Western and Central Europe came from Ecuador, two times the amount reported in 2018, found a United Nations report.

;

;Large drug seizures have become more common within the past month. European officials have made record-setting seizures after inspecting containers carrying bananas from Ecuador.

;

;Officials on August 25 announced Spain's biggest cocaine seizure yet: 9.5 metric tons hidden among boxes of bananas from Ecuador in a ;refrigerated; container. Dutch officials also made their country's largest-ever cocaine seizure last month — nearly 8 metric tons — in a container of Ecuadorian bananas. Officials in Greece and Italy also announced seizures of cocaine hidden in Ecuadorian bananas this year.

;

;Knowingly or not, banana growers, exporters, shipping companies, port operators, private security companies, ;customs; agents, agriculture officials, police, and buyers can be used by drug traffickers.

;

;Some traffickers have created false companies to look like real banana exporters. Others have taken control of legal businesses, including plantations. They have found companies willing to cooperate in trafficking. They have also paid off, threatened or kidnapped truck drivers and other workers to help get cocaine into shipments.

;
;;;FILE - This file picture provided on Aug. 10, 2023 by the Rotterdam Public Prosecution Service shows 8,000 kilograms (17,637 pounds) of cocaine in Rotterdam, Netherlands. (Openbaar Ministerie, Netherlands Public Prosecution Service via AP, File);
;

;Violent deaths in Ecuador have doubled from 2021 to 2022, when 4,600 died, the most ever recorded in a year. The country is likely to break the yearly record again, with 3,568 violent deaths recorded in the first half of 2023. In Guayaquil, people live in fear.

;

;No more than 30 percent of containers are currently inspected at Ecuadorian ports. President Guillermo Lasso's government says it wants to use ;scanners; on entire containers. Twelve of those machines were supposed to be operating already but that has not happened yet, said National Police General Pablo Ramírez. He is Ecuador's national director of anti-drug investigations.

;

;Jose Hidalgo is director of the Association of Banana Exporters of Ecuador. He said the industry is more ;vulnerable; to trafficking than other export products because of the number of containers that it uses.

;

;He explained that exporters spend about $100 million yearly on security measures. That includes ;surveillance; cameras at plantations, GPS ;monitoring; of trucks, and the identification of land routes that require police patrols to keep criminals away.

;

;Still, some exporters have been accused of being involved in trafficking cocaine. The organization behind the cocaine seizure in Spain operated through a banana exporting company in Machala, a city south of Guayaquil.

;

;After this story was published in The Associated Press, agriculture and customs officials in Ecuador announced in a statement that they had removed a government-run banana export database. It removed information on export companies considered to be false or incomplete. It also canceled permits of plantations covering 16,000 hectares found to be nonexistent.

;

;I'm Dan Novak.

;

;The United Nations said the ;magnitude; 6.8 earthquake affected 300,000 people. The damage was great because the starting point of the shaking was not far below the ground.

;
;;;The 6.8-magnitude quake struck the Atlas mountains southwest of the tourist centre of Marrakesh. It killed at least 2,681 people and injured over 2,500 others, according to the latest official toll. (Photo by Philippe LOPEZ / AFP);
;

;The US Geological Survey said it was the strongest quake to strike the North African nation since 1900. And, it is reported to be country's deadliest since 1960, when at least 12,000 people were killed in and near the city of Agadir.

;

;;Offers of help;

;

;So far, Morocco has accepted assistance from four countries – Spain, Qatar, Great Britain and the United Arab Emirates. Other nations have offered help, as well.

;

;But, the Moroccan government says it wants to avoid a “;counterproductive;” lack of ;coordination; by accepting help from too many countries.

;

;One survivor, Salah Ancheu, called the earthquake “a ;catastrophe;” even as a truckload of soldiers arrived in Amizmiz to help. “We don't know what the future is. The aid remains ;insufficient;,” the 28-year-old said.

;

;Mountainside homes and the tower of the local mosque fell down.

;

;Groups from the Moroccan army left Monday from Amizmiz to move into the small mountain villages. Heavy equipment was sent to clear the roads and both visitors and residents lined up to give blood.

;
;;;Asia, 4, whose mother has died, washes her face, next to family destroyed house, in the aftermath of a deadly earthquake, in Tikekhte, near Adassil, Morocco, September 11, 2023. (REUTERS/Nacho Doce);
;

;Some news reports said villagers wept as they saw dead bodies being carried through the streets.

;

;A number of nations said they were ready, but not yet permitted to send help. The group Rescuers Without Borders said about 100 teams, totaling 3,500 rescuers, are prepared to help.

;

;France said four of its citizens died. It has offered assistance but has not been given permission to send rescuers.

;

;In the Czech Republic, 70 rescuers are waiting at an airport for permission to enter Morocco. In Germany, a rescue team of 50 was sent home after waiting at an airport.

;

;A spokesperson from the German foreign ministry said Morocco's refusal of aid from some nations should not be seen as political. “I'm sure they have thought very carefully about which forces can be deployed and how they can get there,” the spokesperson said.

;

;French Foreign Minister Catherine Colonna said France has offered more than $5 million in support. She said Morocco's decision on that offer is its own to make and “must be respected.”

;

;;People sleeping outside;

;

;Many people continue to sleep outside, fearing smaller earthquakes that often follow a major one.

;

;In the village of Imgdal, women and children gathered outside and some kept warm around an open fire on Monday morning.

;

;In another village, Tafeghaghte, Hamid ben Henna said his 8-year-old son died in the quake. He had gone to another room while the family was sharing a meal Friday. The rest of the family survived.

;
;;;A tractor removes rubble as people search for their belongings in their home which was damaged by the earthquake, in the village of Tafeghaghte, near Marrakech, Morocco, Monday, Sept. 11, 2023. (AP Photo/Mosa'ab Elshamy);
;

;On a road near the town of Adassil, close to the center of the quake, one rescue worker was trying to clear the rocks that were preventing vehicles from getting by.

;

;He said other roads were in bad shape. “We're trying to open them, too,” said Ayman Koait.

;

;People said they dug through the rubble of their homes looking for relatives. They also moved rocks and walls looking for important items.

;

;Many of the homes are made from wood, rock, and mud, which made them fall easily when the ground started shaking.

;
;;;A view shows damage at an old mosque in the historic city of Marrakech, following a powerful earthquake in Morocco, September 9, 2023. (REUTERS/Abdelhak Balhaki);
;

;One military worker said “it is difficult to pull people out alive” because the walls turned to rubble and did not leave any space for air.

;

;UNESCO, the United Nations cultural organization, said many historic buildings in both Marrakech and the areas closer to the center of the earthquake were damaged.

;

;I'm Dan Friedell.
